title: A failed company won't pay its debts. One of the creditors is coming after me. How do I stop a creditor from attacking me.
question: The company closed its doors over a year ago and I still have not been paid my wages or PTO and they won't pay this debt. I was a manager and was given permission from my district manager to sign a contract for a phone book add. The contract wanted a principle to sign, however I signed my name with "manager" after. I had no ownership in the company. The creditor is trying to garnish my wages and has reported it on my credit report.
answers:
From the facts you include in your question, it appears that you may have a valid defense if you are sued, file an Answer to the lawsuit and go to court. However, you mention that the creditor is attempting to garnish your wages. A wage garnishment can be done only after the court enters a judgment against you. If you are sued, you must respond by filing the proper papers with the court. If your employer has received any garnishment paperwork from the Sheriff, get a copy and get the case number. Then go to the courthouse and inspect the court's case file. Get a copy of the relevant documents and see an attorney. Do this today.

You no lawsuit has been filed against you, and you are only receiving harassing duns from a debt collector, monitor your credit report. Do not waste you time and energy arguing with the debt collector. Just ignore the duns. Do not ignore a Summons and Complaint.

Lawsuit and judgement stage is important.
In that stage you show the judge that it was the company's ad and that you were acting as the company's agent.

Contact a local lawyer and give him the WHOLE story so that it can be understood whether or not a suit has yet occurred and where you are in this process.

If there is a wage garnishment in process it must be related to a lawsuit not indicated in your facts. You need to defend if you are named individually. If the company was properly formed and maintained before it failed, the shareholders, officers and directors should have no liability. "Managers" are not corporate officers and neither managers nor employees should have any personal liability for company debts. Do not ignore any lawsuits and consult an attorney if you are served.
